text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in Finnish papers this morning.
HELSINGIN SANOMAT
- Finnish Foreign Minister Tarja Halonen said it looked uncertain whether the European Union would manage to hold its Amsterdam summit meeting on schedule at beginning of next week.
- Powerful Finnish paper workers union rejected in advance a centralised collective pay deal and said it would seek a contract at the union level, rather than at federation level. @
- Collective pay deal negotiated in 1995 has had a positive impact on the Finnish economy by raising employees' purchasing power, economists say.
- The Nordic countries have gained popularity among international investors -- shares accounting for over 40 percent of the market capitalisation of the Helsinki bourse are foreign-owned.
- Finland will keep its seat in the European Commission, Prime Minister Paavo Lipponen says. @
- Finland's municipalities are expected to rake in corporate tax revenues this year of 12 billion markka, which is about five billion more than budgeted.
- Very shy people can now get surgical relief for their blushing and sweaty hands, a Finnish doctor says.
KAUPPALEHTI
- Finnish Forest Industry Federation official says paper workers union is endangering European cooperation with its strong statements on monetary union and rejection of a broad pay deal. @
- Sales of first GSM phones by Finnish mobile phone maker Benefon during their first month on the have been modest, retailer says.
- Finnish forestry group Enso ENYRV.HE now has its own international photography collection with works by 17 photographers.
TURUN SANOMAT
- Mention of the markka would be removed from the Finnish constitution if parliament decides to adopt the euro, parliamentary constitutional committee says. @

- Finland and Belgium are ready to add a protocol on employment and economic policy coordination to the stability pact to meet French demands, Belgian Prime Minister Jean-Luc Dehaene and Prime Minister Paavo Lipponen said on Wednesday.
- Backing out of the EMU process would only harm the Finnish economy, Merita Bank's CEO Vesa Vainio says.
- A broad pay deal in still possible, Prime Minister Lipponen says, even though the paper workers union rejected a centralised wage package on Wednesday. @
AAMULEHTI
- In crisis situations, Finnish police would be able to raise a reserve force of 3,000 men, Interior Ministry plans.
-- Nora Hallberg, Helsinki Newsroom +358-9-680 50 292
